title: Lambton Jaffas and Broadmeadow to clash in 2025 Charity Shield | Newcastle Herald
body_text:
Lambton coach David Tanchevski expects the Charity Shield showdown with NPL Northern NSW premiers and champions Broadmeadow to provide a season yardstick for his new-look side.

Northern NSW Football confirmed on Wednesday the two NPL heavyweights would face off for a second consecutive year in the men's pre-season charity match at Jack McLaughlan Oval on Friday, February 7.
NPL champions Charlestown Azzurri, who have signed Magic quartet Kalista Hunter, Madi Gallegos, Kobie Ferguson and Kiarra Lewis, take on State Cup winners Newcastle Olympic in the women's game.
The Charity Shield double-header, raising proceeds for Hunter Medical Research Institute, was introduced last year.
Magic kicked off a successful 2024 campaign by securing the shield with a 3-1 win over the back-to-back NPL grand final winners before going on to claim the premiership-championship double.
They ended Lambton's remarkable 27-game unbeaten streak in the process and finished three points clear of second-placed Jaffas in the points race.
While Magic's squad remains largely unchanged, Lambton have sustained key losses in experienced forwards Kale Bradbery and Ben Hay to Olympic plus defensive midfielder Reece Papas to Azzurri.
They have signed midfielder Joey Langlois and striker Lachlan Griffiths from Olympic plus attacking player Sam Donnellan from Magic.
"We've lost some experience, which is a big hole for us to fill ... but we'll bring in a bit of youth and mobility and try to work with that," Tanchevski said.
"Hopefully we get the right mix and balance of youth and experience and compete again next year.
"It will be a good test going into the season. Magic are a pretty similar team to last year and they'll probably be the team to beat again, so for us it will be a good benchmark to see where we sit after some changes to the squad."
Magic coach Jim Cresnar hoped to pick up where they left off this year with a strong showing in the Charity Shield before the season proper begins one week later.
"It's a game that's important to us to win," Cresnar said.
"It's a Charity Shield, but at the same time we want to make sure we're competitive and get an outcome.
"Over last season, I thought we definitely matured. We worked on a few areas that we needed to work on, which was creeping in during the first part of the season. We were clever enough to correct it in the second half of the season and I think we only lost one game during the second half of the season."
Magic could lose this year's leading scorer Bailey Wells, who is trialling with A-League side Brisbane Roar this month.
The women's match will be a replay of this year's grand final, which Azzurri won 3-2.
Both teams are looking strong again in 2025.
Olympic have been boosted by the return of experienced midfielder Laura Hall after having a baby and have also signed former A-League defender Alex Huynh plus fullback Maddy Howard from Maitland.
The women's NPL has been reduced to a seven-team competition next year after Mid Coast withdrew their senior teams while Lake Macquarie City have replaced Warners Bay.
